Topic.Title: Why are so many on this board so jealous of me?

Message.Msg: I think it`s that little lost boy cheeky-but-inocuous-teenager quality. The one that still needs attention and direction, that seeks attention through disruption and automatic contrariness of sorts but is not yet jaded and bitter enough to capitulate to mean-spirited projections and caustic retaliations--struggling with his default but benign contrariness as a habit, wanting to connect but bored and dissatisfied with all the conventional avenues of normal interaction and not yet having found a more imaginative solution to this and his non-acute but restless inner exile and denied feelings of dejection. ALOL (Almost Laugh Out Loud). But the half-life of teenager-cuteness eventually gives way to futility and annoyance--even for the most patient and loving of parents. So straighten up and fly right. And if that`s too much to ask then just surrender and submit completely to the unmitigated and hopeless juvenility like so many others and...Git `r done!!!

Message.Msg: Steve Wozniak related in an interview: I simply like triple digit numbers with all the things I'm involved with, the cost of making the Apple 1 was around $540 or there about and we agreed on the best markup, retail price above the cost of building it, which worked out to $666. Message.Title: justIn: Apple's 7.85-inch iPad supply volume to reach 4M units
Message.Msg: Apple's (AAPL) 7.85-inch iPad sales volume will reach 4M units per month starting in September, reports DigiTimes. Citing sources from the upstream supply chain, the company has already started supply a small volume of the iPad in juen with a monthly volume at around several hundred thousand.

Message.Title: Williams Attacks Obama During Iowa State Fair Concert
Message.Msg: Country music legend Hank Williams Jr. did not spare any criticism for President Barack Obama during a weekend performance at the Iowa State Fair. After the song, “We Don’t Apologize For America” a chant of “USA, USA” broke out among the 8,500 people at the Grandstand on Friday night, the Des Moines Register reports. Williams, 63, smiled, telling the crowd that he was their mouth piece before adding, “We’ve got a Musslim president who hates farming, hates the military, hates the US – and we hate him!” The crowd roared with loud and enthusiastic cheers, the Register reported.

Message.Title: === MOVING AVERAGES & PARABOLIC STOCKS ===
Message.Msg: No stock in the history of the markets has ever gone permanently parabolic. No stock ever defies the mean of moving averages. No trading robot IGNORES parabolic stocks that imply a defiance of moving averages. No hedge fund manager is stupid enough to leave a heep of cash profit on the table given the above scenario, because EVERY hedge fund manager has seen this done hundreds of times before. The name "APPLE" isn't a shield from profit taking. Profit taking on average will DECIMATE a parabolic stock move. Stocks that trade in the way Apple has traded over the last few weeks always end things badly. No stock EVER defies the order of the universe and avoids gravity... No stock that makes heinous gains in a short period of time ever avoids profit taking No stock will perpetually go up on HYPE and HYPE alone. (Is the iPhone5 actually selling in the marketplace? (No.) Have you actually seen an iTV box and is it outselling Direct TV, Dish, etc? (no) You see? it's all hype, it isn't fact. Apple isn't succeeding with these devices in an already SATURATED market, it's only a rumor of success. Rumors do not constitute fact. Apple faces a growing mass of litigation. Apple products may be restricted (by court order) from being sold in the USA at any moment. Large Institutions and Wall Street Crooks DO NOT want to be left holding the bag on a stock they know *can not* possibly match the implied market metrics. Apple, CAN NOT match the implied metrics given to the stock price based on a product that will not meet the market's suggested valuation of it. In other words, the 'potential' iPhone5 sales are pipe dreams being promoted to you via media hype... the iPhone5 might not even make it to market if Apple is whacked with an injunction, and it certainly won't succeed given the market saturation of other devices. Apple is a "has been". It's already over the hill. We are witnessing the last glorious momentum flame out price spikes at this moment in time. This stock is consistently manipulated in extended trading sessions. How do I know? It's simple. If an investor were really interested in the stock, they would purchase it in the regular session. They wouldn't wait until 30 seconds after the market closes and THEN jump in to buy the stock at a much higher price than the stock was trading just 30 seconds prior. Before you suggest that it is margin calls / short covering moving the price, let me remind you that for one to short this stock, they need a little bit of a bankroll, and anyone shorting it isn't a foolish pond-skimmer or a #$%$. shorts that are scaling into Apple short positions are the smartest folks playing the markets, including the very market makers and pundits that are pumping the stock while they sell it to you.... the naive retail investor. GL!

Message.Title: Need help with this analysis
Message.Msg: If you don`t want to read all of this, skim it down to the bottom. When I follow AAPL`s daily chart to look for trending and momentum, I usually run a 22EMA with a 5SD (standard deviations from the mean) envelope. This normally encompasses 90-95% of its trading range and when it punctures the envelope either or the high or low side it will usually correct back to at least the 22EMA. I will also slap a 7SD envelope on it for extreme cases. In its history when AAPL punctures the 7SD envelope (paralleling a 22EMA), it always (well never say always) corrects back at least through the 22EMA and almost always to the 5SD envelope on the other side and sometimes to the 7SD. This correction can begin anywhere from the same day to 6 days after the breach of the upper 7SD. Some examples going back to 2010: 4/21/10: 14 point gap up from 244 punctures 7SD/22EMA envelope—closes at 259.25. Spike continues for 3 more days above envelope. On 4th day (4/26) from ATH at 272.46 the correction begins. Low swing close on 5/7/10 (about 2 wks. from ATH) at lower 7SD at 235.65—37 point correction—15.7%. Spiked up and back down over next 10 trading days for a double bottom test at 231.35 (punctured the lower 7SD) on 5/21/10. This began the reversal that would eventually test and break the ATH but barely—which leads us to… 6/17/10 Test 272.90 (just under 7SD)—first revisit to ATH since 4/26/10. Next day touches 7SD (but doesn`t puncture) at 275—new ATH. Next day, gaps up, punctures envelope, hits 279 and begins correction the same day. First lowest swing low close on 7/2/10 at 247 almost touching the low 5SD. Next swing low double bottom test on 7/20/10 at 240—around the low 5SD. Next swing low triple bottom test on 8/27/10 at 235—punctured low 5SD. This was the beginning of a long up trend. New ATH tested on 9/17/10 at 277.96 and broke the next trading (Monday) day at 283.78—which leads us to… 9/20/10 Breaks 7SD and stays above it for 5 days reaching ATH 9/27/10 at 294.73—followed by a 5 day all red correction to the 22EMA on 10/4/10 at 277.77 only to reverse and… 10/15/10 punctures 7SD with a strong shear-topped bull spike candle at 315—ATH. Next day gap to 319 only to gap down the next day back through the 7SD. Next lowest swing low on11/17/10 at 297.76. New high broken again 12/6/10 at 322.33. From there it climbed for 5 months but stayed almost exclusively in the 5SD range puncturing it on the low side 3 times—3/16/11 at 326, 4/18/11 at 320.16, and 6/10/11 at 310—almost touching the 7SD on. This began a strong reversal to the up side with an amazing 25 trading-day(s) earnings-run… 7/20/11 Gap up from 376 to 396 puncturing the 7SD where it stayed for 5 more days reaching ATH on 7/26/11 before reversing all the way back down below the low 5SD with a double bottom on 8/8/11 at 353 and again on 8/22/11 at 355… 9/20/11 Broke upper 7SD with ATH 422. Next day began reversal to soon break 7SD on the other side on 10/4/11 at 354. Reversed from there… Spent half a day through the 7SD on 10/17/11 before reversing hard and gapping down hard the following day to eventually retest that bottom on 11/25/11 at 363.32. This marked the beginning of the famous run up to 644. And here is where we get into the long-run parabolic exceptions… 1/25/12 Earnings gap up to ATH of 454.45. This broke the 7SD. Although it fell back through briefly the same day, from that day until April 13 (3 days after 644) it never pulled back to the 22 EMA and only rarely to the 11EMA. From 1/25/12 to 4/10/12. It rode the 7SD, on it, just above it and just below like a snakey sine wave curled around a shooting beanstalk. Then came the correction and now yesterday`s close was on the 7SD. PM we have broken it. So what`s up? Did the beginning of the run to 925 begin on 5/18/12 at 522—similar to the run from 363 to 644 began on 11/25/11? Or are we in for a correction all the way back to 640, 635, 622, 603? Or something in between? Not sure, but I`m not selling yet. When and where is that first pullback? Give yourself a boost.

Message.Title: Rollins: Ryan 'Will Wipe Debate Floor with Biden'
Message.Msg: Republican strategist Ed Rollins says Paul Ryan will "wipe up the floor" with Vice President Joe Biden in the campaign debates this fall, and that the country is hungry for the "substance" the Wisconsin congressman brings to the presidential race. "Ryan is going to be a great articulate spokesperson out there. He is going to wipe up the floor with Biden in the debates," Rollins told Fox News' Sean Hannity Monday night. He added that Mitt Romney's new vice presidential running mate is already providing the kind of "substance . . .the country has been crying for," even if it's focused at the moment on the touchy issues of Medicare and his own budget plan. Rollins, who was a key political adviser to President Ronald Reagan, predicted Ryan "will get stronger" as the race gets tougher because "he's very good on television" and is "getting more confident on the campaign trail."

Message.Title: Topeka: Apple Will Reach Trillion Dollar Market Cap
Message.Msg: Red this you " ASK HOLDS " : BUY BUY BUY !!! for 1/2 price : Apple (AAPL) continues to surge ahead today, to a recent $670.25, after beating Microsoft‘s (MSFT) record and becoming the world’s most valuable company yesterday. Yet that $623.5 billion market cap looks paltry to Topeka Capital Market’s Brian White, who expects the company to reach the one trillion dollar mark. In a note out today, White writes that yesterday’s milestone further demonstrated the company’s ability to overcome market pundits and psychological barriers to further growth. The company’s unique profile and market dominance allowed it to cross the $500 billion line in June without the resistance that other megacaps, from Exxon (XOM) to Cisco (CSCO), have seen, and White expects that the company will go on to set new records where others have faltered, thanks to innovative new products like the iPhone 5 and rumored iPad mini and Apple TV. He has a $1,111 price target on Apple. Read more highlights from his note below: Apple’s P/E of 10.7x (ex-cash) is a Fraction of the 80x for $500B Tech Names. With Apple currently trading at just 10.7x our CY13 EPS estimate (ex-cash; or 13x straight P/E), the stock’s valuation is a fraction of the average P/E of over 80x for the three tech companies that crossed the $500 billion level and the over 60x average for all five companies. At the same time, none of these companies delivered the annual EPS growth that Apple has achieved over the past seven years (i.e., 86%). Apple’s Share is Small but the $500B Companies Were Already Dominant. Another reason why we felt the $500 billion market cap threshold was a fallacy had to do with the dominant market share position of the three leading tech companies versus Apple’s small share. For example, Microsoft held over 90% market share for PC operating systems at the peak cap, while Intel had over 80% of the PC processor market and Cisco had over 70% share in the networking market. On the other hand, IDC estimates Apple held just 4.7% of the PC market in 1Q12 and 6.4% share in the mobile phone market in 2Q12, while Apple’s 68% 2Q12 share of the media tablet market speaks to its invention of the category. Hot New Products to Make Apple the Most Profitable Company Ever. With the help of blockbuster product launches on the horizon with the iPhone 5, “iPad Mini”, Apple TV and potential China Mobile (CHL) relationship, we believe Apple is on a path to generate the highest annual net income of any publicly traded company ever by at least CY13. On average, we estimate Apple’s net income in CY12 will be over 5.6x higher than the three tech companies on an individual basis (when at $500 billion) or 1.7x the aggregate profit of these three companies combined. R

Message.Title: ya think aapl is serious about TV?
Message.Msg: Here’s How Apple Plans to REVOLUTIONIZE Radio and Television By Emily Knapp | Aug 21, 2012 Wall Street Cheat Sheet Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) was granted a patent on Tuesday that would allow users to skip unwanted broadcast segments, such as commercials, with on-device content like songs, podcasts, or other media. U.S. Patent No. 8,249,497, which was granted Apple today, is for “seamless switching between radio and local media.” The patent describes a system in which a mobile device will automatically switch between broadcast content and stored media to offer a unique, customized user experience. Users of devices utilizing this technology would be able to skip sections of content on a radio station, filling the gap with “non-radio media or content sources” already stored on that device. The patent could allow users to skip commercials entirely. Covered by the patent are broadcasts from a “radio stream provided over any communications network,” while the stored media can include content saved in a device’s memory or from a streaming host deviceThe patent essentially outlines technology that switches the station when the content is not to the listener’s liking, filling the space with user-chosen content. It uses metadata from assets like Radio Data System (RDS) data, broadcast listings, or published third-party schedules to “determine when an upcoming broadcast segment or media item is not of interest to the user.” When such an instance is detected, the device will seamlessly switch to stored media until that segment of the broadcast is over, at which point it will switch back. The technology would also analyze audio and video from the source to help discern what kind of content a user may or may not want to consume. The patent employs comparisons of media items to generate a preference profile, much like the system used by Pandora.....

Message.Title: oracle research downgrade here: he gives target of $650 on Apple
Message.Msg: Oracle Investment Cuts Apple To Hold, Stock Backs Off Highs By Teresa Rivas Apple (AAPL) which hit another all-time high this morning, was in the red for the day by the afternoon, falling 0.8% to a recent $660. Yet Oracle Investment Research’s Laurence Isaac Balter thinks the stock could give up more ground. Today he downgraded the stock to Hold, with a $650 price target. (That’s $461 less than Topeka Capital’s $1,111 price target for a trillion-dollar market cap Apple). He is concerned that expectations are too high, especially as investors are pinning their hopes on Apple TV, a push into a new field filled with competitors and potential pitfalls. Still, Balter qualifies the rating as “Hold (for now)” as he advises investors to wait for a clearer demand picture as Apple gears up for expected new product launches. Read his thoughts below: “That’ll do pig, that’ll do.” Reducing to Hold (for now). Reminding me of the ending of the movie “Babe,” AAPL has performed marvelously, exceeding our price target set back in May. However, the hype concerns us, as it sound vaguely familiar to another decade (remember when Microsoft [MSFT] and Cisco [CSCO] were market cap kings?). And just for fun, Apple’s market cap is now equivalent to $87.93 for every man, woman and child on Planet Earth. We believe entering the low margin world of television set top boxes and TV is fraught with margin danger. And will the set top box go on top of the XBOX, next to the DVR or under the DVD Player? Is this the game changer we have all been waiting for? Warren Buffett once quoted Herb Stein, who said “Anything that can’t go on forever…will end.” Sales growth and EPS growth deceleration is alarming and the expectations are high. Tread carefully until we see the next product cycle demand story playing out.

Message.Title: Apple not overvalued
Message.Msg: from CNN Money Asking the following question may be considered blasphemous to the throngs of Mac geeks and iFaithful out there. But here goes: Are shares of Apple (AAPL) finally getting TOO expensive? Apple hit another all-time high Tuesday, coming close to $675 per share before pulling back a bit. The company is now worth approximately $620 billion. That's nearly two-and-a-half times the market value of Microsoft (MSFT) and almost three times what Google (GOOG) is worth. Those two companies are the only tech giants with a market capitalization even remotely close to Apple. So it's fair to wonder if Apple's stock, which is up 63% year-to-date, has risen too far too fast. The good news is that Apple shares are still reasonably valued. It doesn't have a triple-digit price-to-earnings ratio like Cisco (CSCO) did in the late 1990s -- a time when many on Wall Street and Silicon Valley were predicting that Cisco would be the first tech to hit a market value of $1 trillion. Apple's stock is trading at 15 times fiscal 2012 earnings estimates, a fair price for a company whose earnings are expected to increase by 22% annually, on average, over the next few years. But Apple is no longer the slam-dunk bargain it used to be. The earnings multiple is not just keeping pace with earnings growth, it is expanding. When I wrote about Apple nearing an all-time high just a few weeks ago, shares were trading at 14 times earnings estimates. And when Apple's share price topped the $500 mark for the first time back in February, I noted that the stock was trading for less than 12 times fiscal 2012 forecasts. With the end of Apple's fiscal year rapidly approaching, it will soon be time to look at fiscal 2013 predictions as the best gauge for Apple's value. On that front, Apple is not dirt cheap. The stock trades at about 13 times fiscal 2013 estimates. What's more, analysts have been cutting their earnings targets for next year, following Apple's warning that its current quarterly earnings will be below estimates. Now, don't get me wrong: Investors shouldn't be nervous just yet. The company has $117 billion in cash. It's finally using some of that mountain of moolah to pay shareholders a healthy dividend. Doing so makes Apple a stock that both growth-hungry momentum investors and yield-starved income investors can comfortably own. And unless the upcoming iPhone 5 (or will it merely be the "new iPhone"?) looks like Apple's ill-fated Newton from the early 1990s, it seems unlikely that consumers are going to suddenly fall out of love. Competitors like Research and Motion (RIMM) and Nokia (NOK) may be on their last legs, which can only help Apple in the long run. But investors would be foolish to ignore risks. Regardless of what happens with the Apple-Samsung patent infringement trial, Samsung and others that have joined the Google Android camp have emerged as tough competitors. Microsoft, which will soon start selling its Surface Tablet and Windows 8 operating system, seems to have rediscovered its innovative roots. Intel (INTC) is aggressively pushing ultrabooks as an alternative to tablets. Apple is in a business that requires constant product refreshes. There is no time to rest on one's laurels. As soon as the iPhone 5 is out, people will start wondering when the next iPad will be released. Expect even more questions about when Apple will finally reveal the long-rumored Apple TV product, which may or may not be an actual television. And what happens if another company creates a product that makes tablets look obsolete? Just ask Dell (DELL) and HP (HPQ) how sticking with PCs for too long has turned out. "When Apple's stock finally does begin to come down, it will be because of competitive reasons," says David Darst, chief investment strategist with Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. "Valuations are not stretched." True. Shares of Apple may not be overvalued at $670. As long as the company's sales and earnings continue to shine, it could very well surpass $700, $800, and continue its march toward a quadruple-digit stock price and $1 trillion market valuation.

Message.Title: Oracle Investment Research Downgrades AAPL to Hold $650
Message.Msg: Updated - August 21, 2012 2:42 PM EDT) Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) is getting a rare downgrade intra-day Tuesday. Oracle Investment Research downgraded Apple from Buy to Hold with a price target of $650. Analyst Laurence Balter, said the "the hype concerns us, as it sounds vaguely familiar to another decade (remember when Microsoft (Nasdaq: MSFT) and Cisco (Nasdaq: CSCO) were maket cap kings." Apple's market cap is now equal to $87.93 for every person on the planet, he quips. Balter believes there is margin danger with Apple entering the word of set-top-boxes and TVs. He also notes sales growth is deceleration and the expectations are high. "Anything that can't go on forever... will end," Balter quotes Warren Buffett as saying.

Message.Title: MSFT signed deal with NEOM wowww
Message.Msg: NeoMedia licenses mobile barcode patents to Microsoft NeoMedia grants Microsoft worldwide rights to license its patent portfolio http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20120821006384/en Boulder, Colorado, August 21, 2012 – NeoMedia Technologies, Inc. (OTC BB: NEOM), pioneers in the mobile barcode industry, today announced that it has granted Microsoft a worldwide, non-exclusive, license to NeoMedia’s patent portfolio. NeoMedia’s IP portfolio, consisting of over 74 patents awarded and pending worldwide, encompasses many mobile barcode implementations used widely across the industry. “The agreement between NeoMedia and Microsoft underscores the importance of intellectual property to our growing industry,” said Laura Marriott, Chief Executive Officer of NeoMedia. “As mobile barcodes become a key fixture in the mobile marketing mix, it is important for stakeholders across the industry to ensure the solutions they employ leverage the relevant intellectual property in a responsible manner.” “It is a very exciting time for the mobile IP industry as companies develop new technology for the always connected consumer,” said Ragnar Olson, Partner, Global IP Law Group. “We appreciated the opportunity to have worked with NeoMedia to bring about this agreement”

Topic.Title: This board has little good advice and a lot of spam

Message.Msg: Willybird, here's a good opinion for you: No stock in the history of the markets has ever gone permanently parabolic. No stock ever defies the mean of moving averages. No trading robot IGNORES parabolic stocks that imply a defiance of moving averages. No hedge fund manager is stupid enough to leave a heep of profit on the table given the above scenario, because EVERY hedge fund manager has seen this done hundreds of times before. The name "APPLE" isn't a shield from profit taking. Profit taking on average will DECIMATE a parabolic stock move. No stock that makes heinous gains in a short period of time ever avoids profit taking because No stock EVER defies the order of the universe and avoids gravity... No stock will perpetually go up on HYPE and HYPE alone. (Is the iPhone5 actually selling in the marketplace? (No.) Have you actually seen an iTV box and is it outselling Direct TV, Dish, etc? (no) Apple isn't succeeding with these devices in an already SATURATED market, it's only a -rumor- of potential success in the future, MAYBE. Rumors do not constitute fact. Apple faces a growing mass of litigation. Apple products may be restricted (by court order) from being sold in the USA at any moment. Apple, CAN NOT match the implied metrics given to the stock price based on a product that will not meet the market's suggested valuation of it. In other words, the 'potential' iPhone5 sales are pipe dreams being promoted to you via media hype... the iPhone5 might not even make it to market if Apple is whacked with an injunction, and it certainly won't succeed given the market saturation of other devices. Apple is a "has been". It's already over the hill. We are witnessing the last glorious momentum flame out price spikes at this moment in time. This stock is consistently manipulated in extended trading sessions. If an investor were really interested in the stock, they would purchase it in the regular session. They wouldn't wait until 30 seconds after the market closes and THEN jump in to buy the stock at a much higher price than the stock was trading just 30 seconds prior. Before you suggest that it is margin calls / short covering moving the price, let me remind you that for one to short this stock, they need a bankroll, and anyone shorting it isn't a foolish pond-skimmer. Shorts that are scaling into Apple short positions are the smartest folks playing the markets, including the very market makers and pundits that are pumping the stock while they sell it to the naive retail investor.

Message.Title: Winner of AAPL vs Samsung Dispute
Message.Msg: Winner is not Apple nor Samsung. Both companies are just wasting time and money to escalate their bad relationship. The most likely outcome is that Samsung violated some Apple's patents and Apple violated Samsung's patents. Violation by both parties will negate any damages; therefore, neither party will walk away with a monetary award and clear victory...well the attorneys will. Who is the clear winner? Qualcomm....why? Both of these companies have to use products that require a royalty payment to QCOM. Whether it's Android smartphone or iPhone...there will be QCOM chip in there. Let the two big boys slap each other while QCOM laughs to the bank.

Message.Title: A German carrier says a new iPhone is coming in Sep
Message.Msg: updated 12:33 pm EDT, Tue August 21, 2012 Mobilecom Debitel tips hand early A German phone carrier, Mobilecom Debitel, has announced that a new iPhone is coming in September. "In September, it’s finally time for a new generation of smartphone to go on sale. mobilcom-debitel allows you to find free e-mail about everything worth knowing about iPhone," a translation of an announcement email reads. On a teaser page the carrier avoids using the term "iPhone," but does refer to common rumors about the upcoming refresh, such as it getting faster processors, 1GB of RAM, and a 4-inch display with an in-cell touchscreen. Apple is only expected to reveal a new iPhone at a September press event, making Mobilecom's news premature and/or based purely on media reports. Similar slip-ups have happened in the past though, and seem not to have generated much of a firestorm from Apple. At this stage, the company may even welcome the extra publicity.

Topic.Title: OH BOY ... BREAKING! Apple Asking Resellers to Triple iPad Display Space Ahead of Rumored September 12 Media Event

Message.Msg: MacRumors has received word from multiple Apple Premium Resellers in Europe that Apple has requested they set aside additional table space for iPad displays over the next few weeks. One of the sources specifically cites September 12 as the Apple-imposed deadline for the adjustments to be made, while another source indicates that their store is already at work on tripling the amount of display space dedicated to the iPad. We're told that the emphasis on iPad display space is coming at the expense of Apple's Mac Pro and Mac mini computers, which are reportedly being removed from display entirely at these locations. Displays of iPods and associated headphones are also reportedly being trimmed back to release space for the iPad. Apple rendering of partial reseller display layout with increased iPad presence The reasons for the changes are not entirely clear, but the September 12 deadline suggests that they may have something to do with Apple's media event that is widely expected to be held on that date. Apple is expected to introduce the next-generation iPhone at that event, and may also be introducing the "iPad mini". Apple resellers could easily slot the iPad mini into some of display space now being shifted over to the full-size iPad, but it is unclear why Apple would be making these adjustments ahead of time rather than waiting until the iPad mini is announced to revamp the product display mix. Apple is also rumored to be planning to launch a tweaked version of the full-size iPad as soon as next month, with some sources reporting that Apple will primarily be focused on shifting to the company's new, smaller dock connector standard alongside some minor internal changes that will be mostly invisible to users

Message.Title: Juror's Passing Out After the 84 point,109 PG instructions from Judge
Message.Msg: I consider myself a smart person, but after reading through the 109 pages of instructions the judge read to the jury this morning, I couldn't tell where I was or what day of the week it is. Are you kidding me?!? These jurors are simple people and need to here things in simple terms. These lawyers are a joke if they think the juror's are going to remember and follow these instructions. They are more likely to acquit Samsung and run for the doors, instead of serving justice. Unbelievable! NO. 18 SUMMARY OF CONTENTIONS I will now again summarize for you each side's contentions in this case. I will then tell you what each side must prove to win on each of its contentions. As I previously explained, Apple seeks money damages from Samsung Electronics Company ("SEC"), Samsung Electronics America, Inc. ("SEA"), and Samsung Telecommunications America, LLC ("STA"), for allegedly infringing claim 19 of the '381 patent, claim 8 of the '915 patent, claim 50 of the '163 patent, and the D'889, D'087, D'677, and D'305 patents. Apple also argues that SEC actively induced SEA and STA to infringe the patents. Apple also contends that Samsung's infringement has been willful. Samsung denies that it has infringed the asserted claims of Apple's patents and argues that, in addition, those claims are invalid. Invalidity is a defense to infringement. Samsung has also brought claims against Apple for patent infringement. Samsung seeks money damages from Apple for allegedly infringing the '941, '516, '711, '460, and '893 patents by making, importing, using, selling and/or offering for sale Apple's iPhone, iPad and iPod products that Samsung argues are covered by claims 10 and 15 of the '941 patent, claims 15 and 16 of the '516 patent, claim 9 of the '711 patent, claim 1 of the '460 patent, and claim 10 of the '893 patent. Samsung also contends that Apple's infringement has been willful. Apple denies that it has infringed the claims asserted by Samsung and argues that the claims asserted by Samsung are invalid, and for the '516 and '941 patents, exhausted due to Samsung's license to Intel and also unenforceable. Invalidity, exhaustion, and unenforceability are defenses to infringement. Apple also contends that, by asserting its "declared essential" patents against Apple, Samsung has violated the antitrust laws and breached its contractual obligations to timely disclose and then license these patents on fair and reasonable terms. For each party's patent infringement claims against the other, the first issue you will have to decide is whether the alleged infringer has infringed the claims of the patent holder's patents and whether those patents are valid. If you decide that any claim of either party's patents has been infringed and is not invalid, you will then need to decide any money damages to be awarded to the patent holder to compensate for the infringement. You will also need to make a finding as to whether the infringement was willful. If you decide that any infringement was willful, that decision should not affect any damage award you give. I will take willfulness into account later. To resolve Apple's claims regarding Samsung's "declared essential" patents, you will need to make a finding as to whether Samsung violated the antitrust laws and whether Samsung breached its contractual obligations. If you decide that Samsung violated the antitrust laws or breached its contractual obligations, you will then need to decide what money damages to award to Apple. Apple accuses Samsung of diluting Apple's Registered Trade Dress No. 3,470,983. This trade dress relates to the iPhone. Apple also accuses Samsung of diluting two unregistered trade dresses relating to the iPhone. Finally, Apple claims that Samsung has diluted and infringed its unregistered trade dress relating to the iPad. For each of Apple's trade dress dilution and infringement claims, the first issue you will have to decide is whether the Apple trade dress is protectable (or valid). An asserted trade dress is only protectable if the trade dress design as a whole, as opposed to its individual features standing alone, is both distinctive and non-functional. For Apple's trade dress dilution claims, the next issues you will decide are whether Apple's trade dress was famous before Samsung started selling its accused products, and whether Samsung's accused products are likely to cause dilution of the asserted Apple trade dresses by impairing their distinctiveness. Apple's trade dress infringement claim will require you to resolve different issues. You will need to determine whether Apple's trade dress had acquired distinctiveness before Samsung started selling its accused products, and whether Samsung's accused products are likely to cause confusion about the source of Samsung's goods. If you decide that any Apple trade dress is both protectable and has been infringed or willfully diluted by Samsung, you will then need to decide the money damages to be awarded to Apple. Samsung denies that it has infringed or diluted any Apple trade dress and argues that each asserted trade dress is not protectable. If a trade dress is not protectable, that is a defense to infringement and dilution.

Message.Title: Why Apple fears Samsung
Message.Msg: Apple should be afraid of Samsung. Why? Samsung has designed Android smartphone that can do anything iPhone can do and more. Starting 2012, Samsung has released smartphones that has a faster chip and bigger screen than current iPhone 4S. Whatever iPhone can do, Samsung phone can do also. But to some consumers, being able to play videos that require Adobe Flash is a comfort that iPhone users have to live without. Everyone is saying iPhone 5 is going to be better than the latest Samsung phones? Hmm...really? Will it be able to play Adobe Flash videos? No. Will it have a bigger screen? No. Will the new iPhone 5 chip be so much faster than Samsung Galaxy that it will make Samsung look like an outdated device? Answer is no again. It's just iPhone 4S with slightly bigger screen and the latest commercially available chip. iPhone 5 will finally catch up to Samsung's 4G capability. So why the hype? Mainly it's because there are people who just buy for a brand name. Most of the current iPhone users who are eligible for an upgrade will most likely get iPhone 5. But here is the bad news. Apple will no longer be able to easily convince non-iPhone users to buy iPhone 5. Why? Pricing...Samsung is going to subsidize the carriers so that 4G Samsung phones are at least $50 to $100 cheaper and award incentive to carriers to promote Samsung phones over iPhone. If Samsung Galaxy sells for $99 vs iPhone 5 for $199, then consumers may opt for a cheaper Samsung phone. Therefore, new iPhone 5 is going to face a stiffer competition than when iPhone 4S was introduced. Another trend that is sweeping in South Korea is to use a bigger screen smartphone. While iPhone 5 is rumored to increase the screen size to 4 inches, Samsung has already release 5 inch smartphone called Note. Since South Korea leads in a mobile communication, it's important to know how well iPhone does in their market. Prior to release of Samsung Note, iPhone 4S was the most sought smartphone in South Korea. iPhone 4S has now dropped to second place and the new king is Samsung Note. Luckily for Apple, Samsung made a mistake in our market.Currently, Note is exclusively available only through AT&T. A mistake that Samsung will soon correct when Note 2 is announced later this month. Once Note 2 is distributed via all 4 major carriers, iPhone 5 has to compete with 2 competitive products from Samsung (Galaxy 3 and Note 2). the road ahead for iPhone 5 looks tough. Too bad Apple doesn't have Steve Jobs the magician to hype iPhone 5 into a must have gadget. Don't get caught up in iPhone 5 hype. There may be a big sell off once iPhone 5 is released. Take some off the table and buy a company that benefits from iPhone 5 and Samsung smartphones...buy Qualcomm. Regardless who sells the most, QCOM will benefit. I took some profit on AAPL today and bought QCOM. I am long on both AAPL and QCOM, but I see QCOM as a better investment going forward.

Topic.Title: Why Apple fears Samsung

Message.Msg: Samsung's problem is that Android as a whole is markedly inferior when it comes to apps. All the innovative apps come to the iPhone first. It's true that many of the successful ones are ported to Android (sometimes years) later, but the simple fact is that the apps available on the iPhone are superior. The difficulty in launching and supporting an app for the hundreds of different Android devices on the market ensures that we'll continue to see the truly innovative apps from small startups on the iPhone first. As long as Apple continues to enjoy that qualitative advantage, Samsung's products will maintain their "second tier" status in the smartphone world.

Message.Title: Apple, Samsung make final pitch to U.S. jury
Message.Msg: Apple Inc O spent years developing its iconic iPhone, but Samsung took a shortcut by copying its rival's designs after realizing it could not keep up, an Apple attorney said as the high-stakes patent infringement trial drew towards a climax. Closing arguments kicked off on Tuesday at the closely watched trial between Apple and Samsung Electronics Co Ltd in a federal court in San Jose, California. The jury will likely begin deliberating on Wednesday. Samsung attorney Charles Verhoeven countered by saying consumers are not confused between the products from the two mobile companies. He urged jurors to consider that a verdict in favor of Apple could stifle competition and reduce choices for consumers. "Rather than competing in the marketplace, Apple is seeking a competitive edge in the courtroom," Verhoeven said. Apple thinks "it's entitled to having a monopoly on a rounded rectangle with a large screen. It's amazing really." Apple and Samsung are going toe-to-toe in a patents dispute that mirrors the struggle for industry supremacy between the two companies, which control more than half of worldwide smartphone sales. A win for Apple could have a major impact on the industry because the South Korean company's mobile products are run on Google Inc's Android operating system, a popular software that is used by many other manufacturers. Apple attorney Harold McElhinny urged jurors to consider the testimony of a South Korean designer who said she worked day and night on Samsung's phones for three months. "In those critical three months, Samsung was able to copy and incorporate the result of Apple's four-year investment in hard work and ingenuity - without taking any of the risks," McElhinny said. Apple is seeking more than $2.5 billion in damages from Samsung. An Apple expert said Samsung earned 35.5 percent margins on the phones in the lawsuit from mid-2010 through March 2012, on $8.16 billion in U.S. revenue. Samsung has disputed that figure. Apple accuses Samsung of copying the design and some features of its iPad and iPhone, and is asking for a sales ban in addition to monetary damages. Samsung, which is trying to expand in the United States, says Apple infringed several patents, including some for its key wireless technology. BIG CROWD McElhinny laid out what he said was chronological evidence that showed Samsung copied Apple's designs. He also told the jury that, while Apple brought many of its top executives to testify and face cross examination, Samsung had presented no major decision makers. "From the very beginning, Samsung has disrespected this process," he said. McElhinny urged jurors to consider Samsung's internal documents, which compared its products with Apple's and determined it had a crisis of design. Scores of journalists, lawyers, analysts and observers turned out to watch the arguments. By 7:30 a.m. (14:30 GMT) on Tuesday, the line outside the courthouse was nearly a block long. The nine member jury spent over two hours listening to granular legal instructions before Apple's McElhinny began his presentation just after lunch. McElhinny focused on a meeting between Samsung and Google executives in February 2010, where Google asked Samsung to stop imitating the iPad so closely. "Samsung executives chose to ignore that demand and continue on the path of copying," he said. Apple said the products looked so similar that it led to confusion in the marketplace. Samsung's Verhoeven said Apple had not shown any evidence that consumers were actually deceived into buying Samsung products instead of the iPhone or iPad. "Consumers make choices, not mistakes," he said. The trial, which is in its fourth week, has revealed details about the famously secretive maker of the iPhone and iPad, some substantive and some just colorful. An Apple industrial designer described working around a kitchen table with his team to come up with the company's mobile products. Its patent licensing director said Microsoft Corp was one of the few companies to get a license for Apple design patents, but only because Microsoft consented to an anti-cloning provision.

Message.Title: Blomberg NEWS tonight *** GOOGLE Finally Leads in CHINA $$$$$$$ Boohya baby..big
Message.Msg: Google Finally Leads in China -- in App Ad Sales After years of seeing its China strategy hobbled at almost every turn, Google Inc. (GOOG) has finally carved out a market niche where it’s the leader: ads aimed at mobile phone applications. App developers and corporations such as Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW) and Shanghai General Motors Co. (GM) are turning to Google’s AdMob unit to reach Chinese smartphone users on the go. Google’s strength in mobile ads stands in contrast to its search-engine business in China. The global leader has failed to catch homegrown favorite Baidu Inc. (BIDU) in computer-based search, and two years ago Google moved its search servers out of the mainland in a censorship dispute with the government. “Since 2010, Google has been trying many things to keep its presence in China,” said Steven Chang, chief executive officer of ZenithOptimedia’s China division, which buys advertising from Google and Baidu. “AdMob now has quite a significant share of the market.” Thousands of Developers AdMob says it has more than 10,000 registered developers in China. The unit, which Google acquired for $750 million in 2010, says its servers get 7.9 billion requests a month to show ads to mobile-app users in the country. China will overtake the U.S. as the world’s largest smartphone market this year, with shipments climbing 52 percent to 137 million, according to market researcher IDC. AdMob’s key advantage is its reach across smartphone technologies, covering iPhones and iPads as well as Android devices, said Chen Haozhi, chief executive officer of Chukong Co., a maker of mobile Bloomberg news

Topic.Title: AAPL BREAKOUT TO NEW HIGHS -- NO RESISTANCE UP THE CHART -- P&F CHART PRICE TARGET RAISED AGAIN TODAY TO $875.00 !!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Message.Msg: I heard the guy from Oracle...and I agree 100% with what Gene Munster said on reflex....after hearing about the stupid call. Gene said it was a "promotional call...from somebody trying to make a name for himself". And - the jerk was paraded onto the spotlight of the $hill-Network - CN#$%$ During the interview, as I predicted... he referred to the Law of Large Number MYTH. And, he referred to the seasonality of unit sales of the iPhone --- oh what a shocker! (LOL). The guy wore a bow tie for his 2 minutes of CN#$%$ $hill Spotlight time. The $EC should investigate this Oracle guys ties, if any, to Dirty Hed-ge Fu-nd$ linked to CN#$%$ Regardless, the pullback will be shortlived...as AAPL will continue the push higher. Earlier, I read a nice blog piece by Bob Pisani. MUST READ -- See below.... Why Apple Isn't Finished Yet Published: Tuesday, 21 Aug 2012 | 2:38 PM ET By: Bob Pisani CNBC Reporter I have been listening to debates on our air about Apple all morning, particularly about the fact that it is now has the largest market cap ever. The debate has been: is Apple [AAPL 656.062 -9.088 (-1.37%) ] worth it? Can it keep up the innovation? On the surface, the stock is having a tough day — a rare downgrade has caused a reversal, and the stock has given up almost all of its gains from yesterday on very heavy volume. I rarely editorialize on individual stocks, but since I have been a rabid Apple user for a decade I do have a strong opinion, and the answer is, yes, they can keep going. First, one argument against AAPL is its sheer size. Very few companies have ever had market caps over $500 billion, let alone $600 billion: Exxon Mobil [XOM 87.46 -0.49 (-0.56%) ], General Electric [GE 20.85 -0.08 (-0.38%) ], Intel [INTC 26.11 -0.12 (-0.46%) ], Microsoft [MSFT 30.80 0.06 (+0.2%) ] and Cisco [CSCO 19.16 0.22 (+1.16%) ]. The argument is that these companies (with the exception of XOM) eventually fell dramatically, why shouldn't it happen to AAPL? There are several reasons: 1) Apple is not overpriced. Apple is trading at about 11 times forward earnings, at a time when the S&P 500 is trading at almost 14 times forward earnings. According to Topeka Capital Markets, the three tech companies (INTC, MSFT and CSCO) were trading at an average P/E of over 80 times earnings when they passed the $500 billion level. 2) Apple has plenty of room to increase its share of the products it sells. Here's the stats: Apple share of the market for: PCs 4.7% Mobile phones 6.4% Source: IDC/Topeka Capital Yes, it has 68 percent of the tablet market, but it invented that category and it is now facing stiff competition. Compare that to the share of the market that the other $500 billion market cap tech companies had at their height: Microsoft share of PC operating systems 90% Intel share of PC processor market 80% Cisco share of networking market 70% Get it? These other guys already had thoroughly penetrated their markets when they hit those big market caps. They had nowhere to go but down. That is not the case with AAPL. 3) Apple continuously reinvents its products and is growing into new categories. The iPhone 5 is the gift that keeps on giving; millions of Apple users like myself will reflexively go out and buy it. They are working on an iPad "mini." And they may be on the verge of cracking the TV conundrum. They have tried for years to get a foothold in TV, and have fallen short. But word that they are now working on a set-top box that can deliver a cable feed, rather than a full-scale TV, may be just the right approach. Forget the hardware, create software that is linked to iTunes. The problem: it's not clear they can get buy-in from cable companies. But just wait until the numbers get worse, and cable companies realize they are losing subscribers faster than they thought. This would integrate the iPad, the iPhone and Macs with iTunes...and cable TV content. Watching anything you want on your iPhone? Heaven! —By CNBC’s Bob Pisani
